change.changenote: Section 1 definition of "adjudicator" BEFORE repealed by 2002-52-22(a), effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

definition.def: means an adjudicator appointed under section 25;

change.changenote: Section 1 definitions of "administrator" and "deputy registrar" were added by 2002-52-22(b), effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).
Section 1 definition of "minister" BEFORE amended by 2002-52-22(c), effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

definition.def: , except in Part 5, means the minister charged by the Lieutenant Governor in Council with the administration of this Act;

change.changenote: Section 1 definition of "registrar" BEFORE amended by 2002-52-22(d), effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

definition.def: means the registrar as defined in the Private Investigators and Security Agencies Act;

change.changenote: Section 1 definition of "employer", paragraph (d) BEFORE amended by 2002-61-16, effective March 14, 2003 (BC Reg 78/2003).

paragraph.paragraphtext: a public body as defined in the Health Authorities Act or a regional health board or community health council established under that Act that operates

change.changenote: Section 1 definition of "conviction" BEFORE amended by 2003-85-60, effective April 1, 2004 (BC Reg 139/2004).

definition.def: includes a conviction for an attempt to commit a relevant offence, a conditional discharge, a disposition under the Young Offenders Act (Canada) and an order under sections 810 and 810.1 of the Criminal Code (Canada);

change.changenote: Section 1 definition of "employer", paragraph (h.1) was added by 2002-75-41(a), effective May 14, 2004 (BC Reg 217/2004).
Section 1 definition of "employer", paragraph (i) BEFORE amended by 2002-75-41(b), effective May 14, 2004 (BC Reg 217/2004).

paragraph.paragraphtext: the holder of a licence or interim permit issued under the Community Care Facility Act, or

change.changenote: Section 1 definitions of "conviction", "relevant offence" and "work with children" BEFORE amended by 2007-28-3(a), (b) and (c), effective January 1, 2008 (BC Reg 386/2007).

definition.def: includes a conviction for an attempt to commit a relevant offence, a conditional discharge, a disposition made before April 1, 2003 under the Young Offenders Act (Canada) as it then was, a sentence under the Youth Criminal Justice Act (Canada) and an order under sections 810 and 810.1 of the Criminal Code (Canada);
means a provision designated in Schedule 1 as a relevant offence and includes a predecessor to that provision;
means working with children directly or having or potentially having unsupervised access to children in the ordinary course of employment or in the practice of an occupation.

change.changenote: Section 1 definitions of "education institution", "education program", "inspector" and "registered student" were added by 2007-28-3(d), effective January 1, 2008 (BC Reg 386/2007).
Section 1 definition of "conviction" BEFORE amended by 2010-34-22(a), effective January 1, 2011 (BC Reg 352/2010).

paragraph.paragraphtext: a conviction for an attempt to commit a relevant offence,
a conditional discharge,
a conviction for which a pardon has been granted by the National Parole Board, continued under the Corrections and Conditional Release Act (Canada),
a disposition, made before April 1, 2003, under the Young Offenders Act (Canada) as it then was,
a sentence under the Youth Criminal Justice Act (Canada),
the use of alternative measures under section 717 of the Criminal Code to deal with an alleged commission of a relevant offence, and
an order under sections 810, 810.1 and 810.2 of the Criminal Code;

change.changenote: Section 1 definition of "employer", paragraph (d) BEFORE amended by 2010-34-22(c), effective January 1, 2011 (BC Reg 352/2010).

paragraph.paragraphtext: a public body as defined in the Health Authorities Act or a regional health board established under that Act that operates

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: a hospital as defined by section 1 of the Hospital Act,

a Provincial mental health facility, a psychiatric unit or a society as defined by section 1 of the Mental Health Act or a mental health clinic or mental health service established by regulations under section 43 of that Act, or
a facility or service related to medical or health care,

change.changenote: Section 1 definition of "employer", paragraph (i) BEFORE amended by 2010-34-22(d), effective January 1, 2011 (BC Reg 352/2010).
Section 1 definition of "employer", paragraph (i.1) was added by 2010-34-22(d), effective January 1, 2011 (BC Reg 352/2010).

paragraph.paragraphtext: the holder of a licence issued under the Community Care and Assisted Living Act, or

change.changenote: Section 1 definition of "outstanding charge" BEFORE amended by 2010-34-22(e), effective January 1, 2011 (BC Reg 352/2010).

definition.def: means a charge or an application under a provision enumerated in Schedule 1 for which an information has been sworn or an application has been made that has not yet resulted in a conviction, acquittal or order by the court;

change.changenote: Section 1 definitions of "specified offence", "vulnerable adult" and "work with vulnerable adults" were added by 2010-34-22(f), effective January 1, 2011 (BC Reg 352/2010).
Section 1 definition of "education program" BEFORE amended by 2009-34-22, effective January 1, 2012 (BC Reg 352/2010).

definition.def: means an education program, offered by an education institution,

paragraph.paragraphtext: that includes a practicum component involving work with children, and
the successful completion of which is a requirement for

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: registration as a member of a governing body designated by regulation, or
authorization under the Independent School Act to provide the services of a teacher;

change.changenote: Section 1 definition of "education program", subparagraph (b) (ii) BEFORE amended by 2011-19-101(a),102, effective January 9, 2012 (BC Reg 239/2011).

subparagraphtext.green: authorization under the Independent School Act to provide the services of a teacher, or

change.changenote: Section 1 definition of "inspector" BEFORE repealed by 2011-19-101(b), effective January 9, 2012 (BC Reg 239/2011).

definition.def: means the inspector of independent schools appointed under the Independent School Act;

change.changenote: Section 1 definition of "director of certification" was added by 2011-19-101(c), effective January 9, 2012 (BC Reg 239/2011).

Section 1 definitions of "criminal record check verification", "criminal record check verification authorization" "municipality", "portable criminal record check", "post secondary institution", "registered specified organization", "specified organization" and volunteer" were added by 2013-8-1(a) and (c), effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Section 1 definition of "education institution" BEFORE amended by 2013-8-1(b), effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013)

definition.def: means a post secondary institution, within the meaning of section 7, that offers an education program;

change.changenote: Section 1 definition of "work with children", paragraph (d) was added by 2013-8-1(d), effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Section 1 definition of "work with vulnerable adults", paragraph (d) was added by 2013-8-1(e), effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Section 1 definitions of "First Nations Education Authority", "FNEA certified teacher" and "FNEA teaching certificate" were added by 2021-29-22, effective November 25, 2021 (Royal Assent).
Section 1 definition of "employer", paragraph (j) BEFORE amended by 2023-10-151, effective March 30, 2023 (Royal Assent).

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a registered member who employs one or more individuals to assist the registered member in carrying on his or her occupation;

change.changenote: Section 1 definition of "specified organization", paragraph (p) BEFORE amended by 2023-10-151, effective March 30, 2023 (Royal Assent).

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a registered member who uses one or more volunteers to assist the registered member in carrying on his or her occupation;

change.changenote: Section 2 (1) BEFORE amended by 2010-34-23(a), effective January 1, 2011 (BC Reg 352/2010).

subsection.subsectiontext: The purpose of this Act is to help prevent the physical and sexual abuse of children by requiring individuals to whom this Act applies to undergo criminal record checks.

change.changenote: Section 2 (2) BEFORE amended by 2010-34-23(b), effective January 1, 2011 (BC Reg 352/2010).

subsection.subsectiontext: Nothing in this Act is to be interpreted so as to diminish any other requirements that may be imposed under an agreement or any other law on those who work with children.

change.changenote: Section 3 BEFORE amended by 2013-8-2, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

section.sectiontext: The registrar may exempt an individual or organization from all or any provision of this Act if the registrar is satisfied that the individual or organization is subject to a criminal record check process that meets or exceeds the requirements of this Act.

change.changenote: Part 2, heading BEFORE re-enacted by 2007-28-4, effective January 1, 2008 (BC Reg 386/2007).
Section 4 (2) BEFORE amended by 2002-52-23(b) and (c), effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

subsection.subsectiontext: If the registrar determines that the individual who is the subject of the criminal record check has an outstanding charge relating to a relevant offence or has been convicted of a relevant offence, the registrar must promptly

paragraph.paragraphtext: refer the matter to an adjudicator to determine whether the conviction or outstanding charge indicates that the individual presents a risk of physical or sexual abuse to children, and

notify the individual and the employer, governing body or minister referred to in Part 5, as the case may be, that the individual has an outstanding charge relating to a relevant offence or has been convicted of a relevant offence and that the matter has been referred to an adjudicator.

change.changenote: Section 4 (3) to (5) BEFORE amended by 2002-52-23(d) and (e), effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

subsection.subsectiontext: In making a determination under subsection (2) (a), the adjudicator must consider the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: whether the behaviour associated with the relevant offence would, if repeated, pose a threat of physical or sexual abuse to children;
the circumstances of the offence including the age of the individual at the time of the offence and the existence of any extenuating circumstances;

any other factors that the adjudicator considers relevant including, without restriction, the time elapsed since the occurrence of the offence or alleged offence, subsequent actions of the individual, the likelihood of the individual repeating a similar kind of behaviour and any attempts at rehabilitation.

subsection.subsectiontext: The adjudicator must promptly notify the following persons of the determination under subsection (2) (a):

paragraph.paragraphtext: the registrar;
the individual;
the employer, if the individual is an employee or an applicant for employment;
the governing body, if the individual is a registered member or an applicant for registration;
the Minister of Women's Equality, if the individual is a child care provider or an applicant as defined in Part 5.

subsection.subsectiontext: The adjudicator must provide written reasons for the determination under subsection (2) (a) to a person referred to in subsection (4), if the person so requests.

change.changenote: Section 4 (4) (a) BEFORE amended by 2002-52-23(e), effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

paragraph.paragraphtext: the registrar;

change.changenote: Section 4 (4) (e) BEFORE amended by 2002-52-24, effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

paragraph.paragraphtext: the Minister of Women's Equality, if the individual is a child care provider or an applicant as defined in Part 5.

change.changenote: Section 4 (1) BEFORE amended by 2002-52-23(a), effective October 1, 2002 (BC Reg 238/2002).

subsection.subsectiontext: When the registrar receives a criminal record check authorization, the registrar must carry out a criminal record check on the individual who authorized the criminal record check.

change.changenote: Section 4 (2) (b) BEFORE amended by 2007-28-5(a), effective January 1, 2008 (BC Reg 386/2007).

paragraph.paragraphtext: notify the individual and the employer, governing body or minister referred to in Part 5, as the case may be, that the individual has an outstanding charge relating to a relevant offence or has been convicted of a relevant offence and that the matter has been referred to the deputy registrar.

change.changenote: Section 4 (4) (f) and (g) were added by 2007-28-5(b), effective January 1, 2008 (BC Reg 386/2007).
Section 4 (2) BEFORE amended by 2010-34-24(a) and (b), effective January 1, 2011 (BC Reg 352/2010).

subsection.subsectiontext: If the registrar determines that the individual who is the subject of the criminal record check has an outstanding charge relating to a relevant offence or has been convicted of a relevant offence, the registrar must

paragraph.paragraphtext: refer the matter to the deputy registrar to determine whether the conviction or outstanding charge indicates that the individual presents a risk of physical or sexual abuse to children, and

notify the individual and the employer, governing body, education institution or inspector or the administrator referred to in Part 5, as the case may be, that the individual has an outstanding charge relating to a relevant offence or has been convicted of a relevant offence and that the matter has been referred to the deputy registrar.

change.changenote: Section 4 (3) (a) BEFORE amended by 2010-34-24(c), effective January 1, 2011 (BC Reg 352/2010).

paragraph.paragraphtext: whether the behaviour associated with the relevant offence would, if repeated, pose a threat of physical or sexual abuse to children;

change.changenote: Section 4 (2) (b) BEFORE amended by 2011-19-103, effective January 9, 2012 (BC Reg 239/2011).

paragraph.paragraphtext: notify the individual and the employer, governing body, education institution or inspector or the administrator referred to in Part 5, as the case may be, that the individual has an outstanding charge relating to a relevant offence or specified offence or has been convicted of a relevant offence or specified offence and that the matter has been referred to the deputy registrar.

change.changenote: Section 4 (4) (g) BEFORE amended by 2011-19-103, effective January 9, 2012 (BC Reg 239/2011).

paragraph.paragraphtext: the inspector, if the individual is an individual referred to in section 17.5 (1).

change.changenote: Section 4 (1) BEFORE amended by 2013-8-3(a), effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: When the registrar receives a criminal record check authorization and the prescribed fee, the registrar must carry out a criminal record check on the individual who authorized the criminal record check.

change.changenote: Section 4 (2) (b) BEFORE amended by 2013-8-3(b), effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

paragraph.paragraphtext: notify the individual and the employer, governing body, education institution or director of certification or the administrator referred to in Part 5, as the case may be, that the individual has an outstanding charge relating to a relevant offence or specified offence or has been convicted of a relevant offence or specified offence and that the matter has been referred to the deputy registrar.

change.changenote: Section 4 (4) and (5) BEFORE amended by 2013-8-3(c), effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: The deputy registrar must promptly notify the following persons of the determination under subsection (2) (a):

paragraph.paragraphtext: the individual;
the employer, if the individual is an employee or an applicant for employment;
the governing body, if the individual is a registered member or an applicant for registration;
the administrator, if the individual is a child care provider or an applicant as defined in Part 5,
the education institution, if the individual is a registered student or an applicant for registration;
the director of certification, if the individual is an individual referred to in section 17.5 (1).

subsection.subsectiontext: The deputy registrar must provide written reasons for the determination under subsection (2) (a) to a person referred to in subsection (4), if the person so requests.

change.changenote: Section 4 (4.1) and (4.2) were added by 2013-8-3(c), effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Section 4 (2) (b) (viii) was added by 2021-29-23(a), effective November 25, 2021 (Royal Assent).
Section 4 (5) (g) was added by 2021-29-23(b), effective November 25, 2021 (Royal Assent).
Section 4.1 was enacted by 2013-8-4, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Section 5 BEFORE amended by 2002-52-25, effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

subsection.subsectiontext: The individual who is the subject of a criminal record check may appeal the determination of the adjudicator under section 4 by serving the registrar with written notice within 14 days after the day on which the adjudicator notifies the individual of the determination.
When the registrar receives a notice within the time limited for an appeal under subsection (1), the minister must

paragraph.paragraphtext: appoint an appeal panel consisting of 3 members to hear and decide the appeal, and
designate one of the members as the chair of the appeal panel.

subsection.subsectiontext: On an appeal under this section, the appeal panel must review the adjudicator's determination and any records on which it was based and may, but need not, do one or both of the following in conducting the review:

paragraph.paragraphtext: request additional information from the appellant;
convene a hearing.

subsection.subsectiontext: After conducting a review under subsection (3), the appeal panel may, by order, confirm the determination of the adjudicator or overturn the determination and direct that the individual does not present a risk of physical or sexual abuse to children.
The members of the appeal panel have the powers, protection and privileges of a commissioner under sections 12, 15 and 16 of the Inquiry Act.
The appeal panel may determine its own procedures and may receive or accept evidence whether or not it would be admissible in a court of law.
The appeal panel must promptly notify the following persons of the decision reached under subsection (4):

paragraph.paragraphtext: the registrar;
the individual;
the employer, if the individual is an employee or an applicant for employment;
the governing body, if the individual is a registered member or an applicant for registration;
the Minister of Women's Equality, if the individual is a child care provider or an applicant as defined in Part 5.

subsection.subsectiontext: The appeal panel must provide written reasons for the decision reached under subsection (4) to a person referred to in subsection (7), if the person so requests.

change.changenote: Section 5 (7) (e) and (f) were added by 2007-28-6, effective January 1, 2008 (BC Reg 386/2007).
Section 5 (6) (b) BEFORE amended by 2010-34-25, effective January 1, 2011 (BC Reg 352/2010).

paragraph.paragraphtext: overturn the determination of the deputy registrar and direct that the individual does not present a risk of physical or sexual abuse to children.

change.changenote: Section 5 (7) (f) BEFORE amended by 2011-19-103, effective January 9, 2012 (BC Reg 239/2011).

paragraph.paragraphtext: the inspector, if the individual is an individual referred to in section 17.5 (1).

change.changenote: Section 5 (1), (7) and (8) BEFORE amended by 2013-8-5, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: The individual who is the subject of a criminal record check may request a reconsideration of the determination of the deputy registrar under section 4 by serving the registrar with written notice within 30 days after the day on which the deputy registrar notifies the individual of the determination.
The registrar must promptly notify the following persons of the decision reached under subsection (6):

paragraph.paragraphtext: the individual;
the employer, if the individual is an employee or an applicant for employment;
the governing body, if the individual is a registered member or an applicant for registration;
the administrator, if the individual is a child care provider or an applicant as defined in Part 5;
the education institution, if the individual is a registered student or an applicant for registration;
the director of certification, if the individual is an individual referred to in section 17.5 (1).

subsection.subsectiontext: The registrar must provide written reasons for the decision reached under subsection (6) to a person referred to in subsection (7), if the person so requests.

change.changenote: Section 5 (8) (g) was added by 2021-29-24, effective November 25, 2021 (Royal Assent).
Section 6 (1) BEFORE amended by 2002-52-26(a), effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

subsection.subsectiontext: The following persons must provide any records that an adjudicator or appeal panel may, by order, require for the purpose of making a determination under this Part with respect to an individual:

change.changenote: Section 6 (1) (c) BEFORE amended by 2002-52-24, effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

paragraph.paragraphtext: the Minister of Women's Equality, if the individual is a child care provider or an applicant as defined in Part 5.

change.changenote: Section 6 (2) BEFORE amended by 2002-52-26(b), effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

subsection.subsectiontext: If an adjudicator, appeal panel or any other person is required to disclose a disposition under the Young Offenders Act (Canada) or any other information contained in youth records under that Act to an employer, governing body, or other person under this Act, that information must be disclosed only in accordance with the provisions of the Young Offenders Act (Canada).

change.changenote: Section 6 (2) BEFORE amended by 2003-85-61, effective April 1, 2004 (BC Reg 139/2004).

subsection.subsectiontext: If the registrar, the deputy registrar or any other person is required to disclose a disposition under the Young Offenders Act (Canada) or any other information contained in youth records under that Act to an employer, governing body, or other person under this Act, that information must be disclosed only in accordance with the provisions of the Young Offenders Act (Canada).

change.changenote: Section 6 (3) and (4) BEFORE amended by 2004-64-17, effective October 21, 2004 (Royal Assent).

subsection.subsectiontext: Information provided under this Act must not be used or disclosed for any purpose other than the purpose set out in section 2 of this Act or in section 33 (n) or (p) or 44 (2) or (3) of the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act.
Subsection (3) applies despite any provision of the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act other than sections 33 (n) and (p) and 44 (2) and (3) of that Act.

change.changenote: Section 6 (1) (d) and (e) were added by 2007-28-7, effective January 1, 2008 (BC Reg 386/2007).
Section 6 (1) (f) was added by 2010-34-26, effective January 1, 2011 (BC Reg 352/2010).
Section 6 (1) (e) BEFORE amended by 2011-19-103, effective January 9, 2012 (BC Reg 239/2011).

paragraph.paragraphtext: the inspector, if the individual is an individual referred to in section 17.5 (1);

change.changenote: Section 6 (3) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 243/2013 effective November 28, 2013.

subsection.subsectiontext: Information provided under this Act must not be used or disclosed for any purpose other than the purpose set out in section 2 of this Act or in section 33.1 (l) (m), 33.2 (i) or 44 (2) or (3) of the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act.

change.changenote: Section 6 (1) (g) was added by 2013-8-6, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Section 6 (1) (i) was added by 2021-29-25, effective November 25, 2021 (Royal Assent).
Section 6 (3) BEFORE amended by 2021-39-55, effective November 25, 2021 (Royal Assent).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Information provided under this Act must not be used or disclosed for any purpose other than the purpose set out in section 2 of this Act or in section 33.1 (1) (m), 33.2 (i) or 44 (2) or (3) of the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act.

change.changenote: Part 2.1 was enacted by 2013-8-7, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Section 7 (1) definition of "post secondary institution", paragraph (b.1) BEFORE repealed by 2002-35-2, effective March 31, 2003 [on repeal of 1997-54-3and 4 (BC Reg 152/2003)].

paragraph.paragraphtext: the Technical University of British Columbia,

change.changenote: Section 7 (1) definition of "municipality" BEFORE amended by 2003-52-46, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing (BC Reg 428/2003).

definition.def: means a municipality as defined in the Local Government Act and includes the City of Vancouver, regional districts and improvement districts;

change.changenote: Section 7 (1) definition of "post secondary institution", paragraph (c) BEFORE repealed by 2004-33-13, effective June 11, 2004 (BC Reg 252/2004).

paragraph.paragraphtext: the British Columbia Institute of Technology, and

change.changenote: Section 7 (1) definition of "post secondary institution", paragraph (d) BEFORE amended by 2004-33-13, effective June 11, 2004 (BC Reg 252/2004).

paragraph.paragraphtext: a college or Provincial institute designated under the College and Institute Act.

change.changenote: Section 7 (1) definition of "post secondary institution", paragraph (b.3) was added by 2005-17-14, effective March 31, 2005 (BC Reg 201/2005).
Section 7 (2) (a) BEFORE amended by 2007-28-8, effective January 1, 2008 (BC Reg 386/2007).

paragraph.paragraphtext: an employee who is subject to a criminal record check under Part 4 as a registered member,

change.changenote: Section 7 (2) (a) BEFORE amended by 2010-34-27, effective January 1, 2011 (BC Reg 352/2010).

paragraph.paragraphtext: an employee who is subject to a criminal record check

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: under Part 4 as a registered member, or
under Part 4.2 as an individual who applies for or holds a certification under section 5 of the Independent School Act or who is specified in a letter of permission under that section,

change.changenote: Section 7 (2) (a) (ii) BEFORE amended by 2011-19-104, effective January 9, 2012 (BC Reg 239/2011).

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: under Part 4.2 as an individual who applies for or holds a certification under section 5 of the Independent School Act or who is specified in a letter of permission under that section,

change.changenote: Section 7 (1) BEFORE repealed by 2013-8-8, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: In this section:

paragraph.paragraphtext: a regional district, and
an improvement district;
a university under the University Act,
the University of Northern British Columbia,
[Repealed 2002-35-2.]
Royal Roads University,
the Thompson Rivers University,
an institution as defined in the College and Institute Act.

change.changenote: Section 8 (1) BEFORE amended by 2007-28-9, effective January 1, 2008 (BC Reg 386/2007).

subsection.subsectiontext: An employer must ensure that every individual who is hired for employment involving work with children and every employee who works with children undergoes a criminal record check.

change.changenote: Section 8 (1) and (3) BEFORE amended by 2010-34-28, effective January 1, 2011 (BC Reg 352/2010).

subsection.subsectiontext: An employer must ensure that every individual who is hired for employment involving work with children and every employee who works with children undergoes a criminal record check in accordance with this Part.

The employer must inform individuals of the requirements of this Act if those individuals are employed by or are applicants for employment with the employer in a job that involves working with children.

change.changenote: Section 8 (1) and (2) BEFORE amended by 2013-8-9(a) and (b), effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: An employer must ensure that every individual who is hired for employment involving work with children or work with vulnerable adults and every employee who works with children or works with vulnerable adults undergoes a criminal record check in accordance with this Part.
Despite subsection (1), an employer must not require an applicant for employment to authorize a criminal record check unless the employer has offered employment to the applicant.

change.changenote: Section 8 (1.1) was added by 2013-8-9(a), effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Section 9 (1) and (2) BEFORE amended by 2010-34-29, effective January 1, 2011 (BC Reg 352/2010).

subsection.subsectiontext: When an individual is offered employment that involves working with children, the individual must provide a criminal record check authorization to the employer.
An employer must not employ an applicant in a job that involves working with children unless the applicant has provided the criminal record check authorization in accordance with subsection (1).

change.changenote: Section 9 (1) and (2) BEFORE amended by 2013-8-10, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: When an individual is offered employment that involves working with children or working with vulnerable adults, the individual must provide a criminal record check authorization to the employer.

An employer must not employ an applicant in a job that involves working with children or working with vulnerable adults unless the applicant has provided the criminal record check authorization in accordance with subsection (1).

change.changenote: Section 10 (1) BEFORE amended by 2007-28-10, effective January 1, 2008 (BC Reg 386/2007).

subsection.subsectiontext: An employee who works with children must provide a criminal record check authorization to his or her employer.

change.changenote: Section 10 (1) (part) BEFORE amended by 2010-34-30(a), effective January 1, 2011 (BC Reg 352/2010).

subsection.subsectiontext: An employee who works with children must provide a criminal record check authorization to his or her employer

change.changenote: Section 10 (2) (a) and (b) BEFORE amended by 2010-34-30(b), effective January 1, 2011 (BC Reg 352/2010).

paragraph.paragraphtext: the employee must not work with children until the employee has provided the criminal record check authorization, and
the employer of the employee must ensure that the employee does not work with children until the employee has provided a criminal record check authorization.

change.changenote: Section 10 (1) and (2) BEFORE amended by 2013-8-11, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: An employee who works with children or works with vulnerable adults must provide a criminal record check authorization to his or her employer

paragraph.paragraphtext: before the date prescribed by regulation, and
at least once every 5 years after the date on which the authorization is provided in compliance with paragraph (a).

subsection.subsectiontext: If an employee does not provide a criminal record check authorization as required by subsection (1) or section 12,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the employee must not work with children or work with vulnerable adults until the employee has provided the criminal record check authorization, and
the employer of the employee must ensure that the employee does not work with children or work with vulnerable adults until the employee has provided a criminal record check authorization.

change.changenote: Section 10 (1) (b) BEFORE amended by 2023-10-152, effective March 30, 2023 (Royal Assent).

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide to his or her employer a criminal record check authorization or a criminal record check verification authorization, as applicable, at least once every 5 years after the date on which the employee provided to his or her employer the employee's last criminal record check authorization or criminal record check verification authorization.

change.changenote: Section 10.1 was enacted by 2013-8-12, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Section 11 BEFORE amended by 2002-52-27, effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

section.sectiontext: If an adjudicator determines that an outstanding charge or conviction indicates that the individual presents a risk of physical or sexual abuse to children and that determination is not overturned by an appeal panel under section 5,

change.changenote: Section 11 BEFORE amended by 2013-8-13, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

section.marginalnote: Effect of finding of risk — working with children
section.sectiontext: If the deputy registrar determines that an outstanding charge or conviction indicates that the individual presents a risk of physical or sexual abuse to children and unless that determination is overturned by the registrar under section 5,

paragraph.paragraphtext: if the individual is an applicant for employment, the employer must ensure that the individual is not hired for a job that involves working with children, or
if the individual is an employee, the employer must ensure that the employee does not work with children.

change.changenote: Section 11.1 was enacted by 2010-34-31, effective January 1, 2011 (BC Reg 352/2010).
Section 11.1 BEFORE renumbered and amended as 11.1(1) and by adding (2) by 2013-8-14, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

section.marginalnote: Effect of finding of risk — working with vulnerable adults
section.sectiontext: If the deputy registrar determines that an outstanding charge or conviction indicates that the individual presents a risk of physical, sexual or financial abuse to vulnerable adults and unless that determination is overturned by the registrar under section 5,

paragraph.paragraphtext: if the individual is an applicant for employment, the employer must ensure that the individual is not hired for a job that involves working with vulnerable adults, or
if the individual is an employee, the employer must ensure that the employee does not work with vulnerable adults.

change.changenote: Section 12 (1) and (2) BEFORE amended by 2010-34-32, effective January 1, 2011 (BC Reg 352/2010).

subsection.subsectiontext: If an employee who works with children is charged with or convicted of a relevant offence subsequent to a criminal record check, the employee must promptly report the charge or conviction to the employee's employer and provide to the employer a criminal record check authorization for a further criminal record check.

When an employer becomes aware that an employee who works with children has an outstanding charge for, or has been convicted of, a relevant offence, the employer must require the employee to provide a criminal record check authorization for a further criminal record check.

change.changenote: Section 12 (1) BEFORE amended by 2013-8-15, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: If an employee who works with children or works with vulnerable adults is charged with or convicted of a relevant offence subsequent to a criminal record check, the employee must promptly report the charge or conviction to the employee's employer and provide to the employer a criminal record check authorization for a further criminal record check.

change.changenote: Section 13 (1) BEFORE amended by 2007-28-11, effective January 1, 2008 (BC Reg 386/2007).

subsection.subsectiontext: A governing body must ensure that every member of the governing body who is registered and every individual who applies for registration undergoes a criminal record check.

change.changenote: Section 13 (1) BEFORE amended by 2013-8-16, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: A governing body must ensure that every member of the governing body who is registered and every individual who applies for registration undergoes a criminal record check in accordance with this Part.

change.changenote: Section 13 (1.1) was added by 2013-8-16, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Section 14 (1) and (2) BEFORE amended by 2013-8-17, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: Before an individual is registered as a member of a governing body, the individual must provide a criminal record check authorization to the governing body.
A governing body must not register an applicant unless the applicant has provided the criminal record check authorization in accordance with subsection (1).

change.changenote: Section 15 (1) BEFORE amended by 2007-28-12, effective January 1, 2008 (BC Reg 386/2007).

subsection.subsectiontext: A registered member must provide a criminal record check authorization to his or her governing body.

change.changenote: Section 15 (2) (a) BEFORE amended by 2010-34-33, effective January 1, 2011 (BC Reg 352/2010).

paragraph.paragraphtext: the registered member must not work with children until the registered member has provided the criminal record check authorization, and

change.changenote: Section 15 (1) and (2) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 2013-8-18, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: A registered member must provide a criminal record check authorization to his or her governing body

paragraph.paragraphtext: before the date prescribed by regulation, and
at least once every 5 years after the date on which the authorization is provided in compliance with paragraph (a).

subsection.subsectiontext: If a registered member does not provide the criminal record check authorization as required by subsection (1) or section 17,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the registered member must not work with children or work with vulnerable adults until the registered member has provided the criminal record check authorization, and
the governing body must investigate or review the registration of the registered member and take appropriate action under the Act that governs the governing body.

change.changenote: Section 15 (1) and (3) BEFORE amended by 2023-10-153, effective March 30, 2023 (Royal Assent).

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: undergo a criminal record check at least once every 5 years, and

provide to his or her governing body a criminal record check authorization or a criminal record check verification authorization, as applicable, at least once every 5 years after the date on which the registered member provided to his or her governing body the registered member's last criminal record check authorization or criminal record check verification authorization.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a registered member carries on his or her occupation as an employee, the governing body must take reasonable steps to notify the registered member's employer that it is taking action under subsection (2) (b).

change.changenote: Section 15.1 was enacted by BC Reg 2013-8-19, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Section 16 (1) BEFORE amended by 2002-52-27, effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

subsection.subsectiontext: If an adjudicator determines that an outstanding charge or conviction indicates that the individual presents a risk of physical or sexual abuse to children and that determination is not overturned by an appeal panel under section 5, the governing body must investigate or review the individual's registration or application for registration and take appropriate action under the Act that governs the governing body.

change.changenote: Section 16 (1), (2) and (3) BEFORE amended by 2010-34-34, effective January 1, 2011 (BC Reg 352/2010).

subsection.subsectiontext: If the deputy registrar determines that an outstanding charge or conviction indicates that the individual presents a risk of physical or sexual abuse to children and unless that determination is overturned by the registrar under section 5, the governing body must investigate or review the individual's registration or application for registration and take appropriate action under the Act that governs the governing body.

If a registered member carries on his or her occupation as an employee, the governing body must take reasonable steps to notify the registered member's employer that the governing body is taking action under subsection (1).
An employer who is notified under subsection (2) must ensure that the employee does not work with children.

change.changenote: Section 16 (1) and (2) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 2013-8-20(a) and (c), effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: If the deputy registrar determines that an outstanding charge or conviction indicates that the individual presents a risk of physical or sexual abuse to children or a risk of physical, sexual or financial abuse to vulnerable adults and unless that determination is overturned by the registrar under section 5, the governing body must investigate or review the individual's registration or application for registration and take appropriate action under the Act that governs the governing body.

If a registered member carries on his or her occupation as an employee, the governing body must take reasonable steps to notify the registered member's employer that the governing body is taking action under subsection (1) and that the action is with respect to a risk to children or to vulnerable adults, whichever is applicable.

change.changenote: Section 16 (1.1) was added by BC Reg 2013-8-20(b), effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Section 16 (2) BEFORE amended by 2023-10-154, effective March 30, 2023 (Royal Assent).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a registered member carries on his or her occupation as an employee, the governing body must take reasonable steps to notify the registered member's employer that the governing body is taking action under subsection (1) or (1.1) and that the action is with respect to a risk to children or to vulnerable adults, whichever is applicable.

change.changenote: Section 17 (1) to (4) BEFORE amended by 2010-34-35, effective January 1, 2011 (BC Reg 352/2010).

subsection.subsectiontext: If a registered member is charged with or convicted of a relevant offence subsequent to a criminal record check, the registered member must promptly report the charge or conviction to the member's governing body and provide to the governing body a criminal record check authorization for a further criminal record check.

When a governing body becomes aware that a registered member has an outstanding charge for, or has been convicted of, a relevant offence, the governing body must require the registered member to provide a criminal record check authorization for a further criminal record check.

If a registered member carries on his or her occupation as an employee, the governing body must take reasonable steps to notify the registered member's employer that the governing body is taking action under subsection (2).

An employer who is notified under subsection (3) must ensure that the employee does not work with children until the employee has provided a criminal record check authorization for a further criminal record check under subsection (1) or (2).

change.changenote: Section 17 (1) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 2013-8-21, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: If a registered member is charged with or convicted of a relevant offence or a specified offence subsequent to a criminal record check, the registered member must promptly report the charge or conviction to the member's governing body and provide to the governing body a criminal record check authorization for a further criminal record check.

change.changenote: Section 17 (3) BEFORE amended by 2023-10-154, effective March 30, 2023 (Royal Assent).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a registered member carries on his or her occupation as an employee, the governing body must take reasonable steps to notify the registered member's employer that the governing body is taking action under subsection (2) and that the action is with respect to a risk to children or to vulnerable adults, whichever is applicable.

change.changenote: Part 4.1, sections 17.1 to 17.4 were enacted by 2007-28-13, effective January 1, 2008 (BC Reg 386/2007).
Part 4.1, heading BEFORE amended by BC Reg 2013-8-22, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Section 17.1 (1) BEFORE amended by 2009-34-36, effective January 1, 2012 (BC Reg 352/2010).

subsection.subsectiontext: An education institution must ensure that every registered student who will work with children undergoes a criminal record check.

change.changenote: Section 17.1 (1) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 2013-8-23, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: An education institution must ensure that every registered student who will work with children or work with vulnerable adults undergoes a criminal record check.

change.changenote: Section 17.1 (1.1) was added by BC Reg 2013-8-23, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Section 17.2 (1) and (2) BEFORE amended by 2009-34-37(a) and (b), effective January 1, 2012 (BC Reg 352/2010).

subsection.subsectiontext: Before working with children, a registered student must provide a criminal record check authorization to his or her education institution.

If a registered student does not provide the criminal record check authorization as required by subsection (1), the registered student must not work with children until the registered student has provided the criminal record check authorization.

change.changenote: Section 17.2 BEFORE re-enacted by BC Reg 2013-8-24, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

section.marginalnote: Registered students working with children or working with vulnerable adults

subsection.subsectiontext: Before working with children or working with vulnerable adults, a registered student must provide a criminal record check authorization to his or her education institution.

If a registered student does not provide the criminal record check authorization as required by subsection (1), the registered student must not work with children or work with vulnerable adults until the registered student has provided the criminal record check authorization.

change.changenote: Section 17.2 (1) BEFORE amended by 2023-10-155, effective March 30, 2023 (Royal Assent).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before working with children or working with vulnerable adults, a registered student must provide to his or her education institution a criminal record check authorization or a criminal record check verification authorization, as applicable.

change.changenote: Section 17.21 was enacted by BC Reg 2013-8-25, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Section 17.3 BEFORE amended by BC Reg 2013-8-26, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

section.marginalnote: Effect of finding of risk — working with children
section.sectiontext: If the deputy registrar determines that an outstanding charge or a conviction indicates that a registered student presents a risk of physical or sexual abuse to children and unless that determination is overturned by the registrar under section 5, the education institution must ensure that the registered student does not work with children as a registered student.

change.changenote: Section 17.31 was enacted by 2009-34-38, effective January 1, 2012 (BC Reg 352/2010).
Section 17.31 BEFORE amended by BC Reg 2013-8-27, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

section.marginalnote: Effect of finding of risk — working with vulnerable adults
section.sectiontext: If the deputy registrar determines that an outstanding charge or a conviction indicates that a registered student presents a risk of physical, sexual or financial abuse to vulnerable adults and unless that determination is overturned by the registrar under section 5, the education institution must ensure that the registered student does not work with vulnerable adults as a registered student.

change.changenote: Sections 17.4 (1) and (2) BEFORE amended by 2009-34-39, effective January 1, 2012 (BC Reg 352/2010).

subsection.subsectiontext: If a registered student who works with children is charged with or convicted of a relevant offence subsequent to a criminal record check, the registered student must promptly report the charge or conviction to the education institution and provide to the education institution a criminal record check authorization for a further criminal record check.

When an education institution becomes aware that a registered student who works with children has an outstanding charge for, or has been convicted of, a relevant offence, the education institution must require the registered student to provide a criminal record check authorization for a further criminal record check.

change.changenote: Section 17.4 (1) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 2013-8-21, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: If a registered student who works with children or works with vulnerable adults is charged with or convicted of a relevant offence or specified offence subsequent to a criminal record check, the registered student must promptly report the charge or conviction to the education institution and provide to the education institution a criminal record check authorization for a further criminal record check.

change.changenote: Part 4.2, sections 17.5 to 17.9 were enacted by 2007-28-13, effective January 1, 2008 (BC Reg 386/2007).
Part 4.2, sections 17.5 to 17.9 BEFORE re-enacted by 2011-19-105, effective January 9, 2012 (BC Reg 239/2011).

subsection.subsectiontext: The inspector must ensure that every individual who applies for or holds a certification under section 5 of the Independent School Act or who is specified in a letter of permission under that section undergoes a criminal record check in accordance with this Part.
The inspector must inform individuals referred to in subsection (1) of the requirements of this Act.

section.marginalnote: New certifications and letters of permission

subsection.subsectiontext: Before a certification or a letter of permission is issued under section 5 of the Independent School Act, the individual to be certified or to be specified in the letter of permission must provide to the inspector a criminal record check authorization.

If an individual does not provide the criminal record check authorization required by subsection (1), the inspector must not issue a certification to the individual or specify the individual in a letter of permission.
A person who holds a certification under section 5 of the Independent School Act must provide a criminal record check authorization to the inspector

paragraph.paragraphtext: before the date prescribed by regulation, and
at least once every 5 years after the date on which the authorization is provided in compliance with paragraph (a).

subsection.subsectiontext: If a person referred to in subsection (1) does not provide a criminal record check authorization as required by subsection (1) or section 17.9,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the person must not work with children until the person has provided the criminal record check authorization, and
the inspector must review the certification and take appropriate action under the Independent School Act.

section.sectiontext: If the deputy registrar determines that an outstanding charge or a conviction indicates that an individual presents a risk of physical or sexual abuse to children and unless that determination is overturned by the registrar under section 5, the inspector must review the individual's application for certification or the proposed letter of permission and take appropriate action under the Independent School Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a person who holds a certification or is specified in a letter of permission under section 5 of the Independent School Act is charged with or convicted of a relevant offence subsequent to a criminal record check, the person must promptly report the charge or conviction to the inspector and provide to the inspector a criminal record check authorization for a further criminal record check.

When the inspector becomes aware that a person who holds a certification or is specified in a letter of permission under section 5 of the Independent School Act has an outstanding charge for, or has been convicted of, a relevant offence, the inspector must require the person to provide a criminal record check authorization for a further criminal record check.

change.changenote: Section 17.41 was enacted by BC Reg 2013-8-28, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Section 17.5 (1) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 2013-8-29, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: The director of certification must ensure that every individual who applies for or holds a certificate of qualification or an independent school teaching certificate issued under section 30 of the Teachers Act undergoes a criminal record check in accordance with this Part.

change.changenote: Section 17.5 (1.1) was added by BC Reg 2013-8-29, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Sections 17.6 to 17.8 BEFORE re-enacted by BC Reg 2013-8-30, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: Before a certificate of qualification or an independent school teaching certificate is issued under section 30 of the Teachers Act, the individual to be certified must provide to the director of certification a criminal record check authorization.

If an individual does not provide the criminal record check authorization required by subsection (1), the director of certification must not issue a certificate of qualification or an independent school teaching certificate to the individual.

A person who holds a certificate of qualification or an independent school teaching certificate under section 30 of the Teachers Act must provide a criminal record check authorization to the director of certification

paragraph.paragraphtext: before the date prescribed by regulation, and
at least once every 5 years after the date on which the authorization is provided in compliance with paragraph (a) of this subsection.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a person referred to in subsection (1) of this section does not provide a criminal record check authorization as required by that subsection or by section 17.9,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the person must not work with children until the person has provided the criminal record check authorization, and
the director of certification must review the certificate of qualification or independent school teaching certificate and take appropriate action under the Teachers Act.

section.sectiontext: If the deputy registrar determines that an outstanding charge or a conviction indicates that an individual presents a risk of physical or sexual abuse to children and unless that determination is overturned by the registrar under section 5, the director of certification must review the individual's application for a certificate of qualification or an independent school teaching certificate and take appropriate action under the Teachers Act.

change.changenote: Section 17.71 was enacted by BC Reg 2013-8-30, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Section 17.9 (1) and (2) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 2013-8-31, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: If a person who holds a certificate of qualification or an independent school teaching certificate under section 30 of the Teachers Act is charged with or convicted of a relevant offence subsequent to a criminal record check, the person must promptly report the charge or conviction to the director of certification and provide to the director of certification a criminal record check authorization for a further criminal record check.

When the director of certification becomes aware that a person who holds a certificate of qualification or an independent school teaching certificate under section 30 of the Teachers Act has an outstanding charge for, or has been convicted of, a relevant offence, the director of certification must require the person to provide a criminal record check authorization for a further criminal record check.

change.changenote: Section 18 definitions of "applicant" and "child care provider" BEFORE amended by 2002-52-28(a), effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

definition.def: means an individual who operates or who intends to operate an unlicensed family child care facility and requests registration for the facility under the Child Care Support Program administered by the Ministry of Women's Equality;
means an individual who operates an unlicensed family child care facility and who is registered under the Child Care Support Program administered by the Ministry of Women's Equality;

change.changenote: Section 18 definition of "minister" BEFORE repealed by 2002-52-28(b), effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

definition.def: means the Minister of Women's Equality;

change.changenote: Section 18 definition of "unlicensed family child care facility" BEFORE amended by 2007-28-14, effective January 1, 2008 (BC Reg 386/2007).

definition.def: means a facility other than a facility under the Community Care Facility Act that offers child care to one or 2 children not related by blood or marriage to the operator of the facility.

change.changenote: Section 19 (1) and (2) BEFORE amended by 2002-52-29, effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

subsection.subsectiontext: The minister must ensure that every individual who requests registration as a child care provider and every child care provider undergoes a criminal record check.
The minister must inform an individual of the requirements of this Act if that individual is a child care provider or requests registration as a child care provider.

change.changenote: Section 19 (1) BEFORE amended by 2007-28-15, effective January 1, 2008 (BC Reg 386/2007).

subsection.subsectiontext: The administrator must ensure that every individual who requests registration as a child care provider and every child care provider undergoes a criminal record check.

change.changenote: Section 19 (1) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 2013-8-32, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: The administrator must ensure that every individual who requests registration as a child care provider and every child care provider undergoes a criminal record check in accordance with this Part.

change.changenote: Section 19 (1.1) was added by BC Reg 2013-8-32, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Section 20 (1) and (2) BEFORE amended by 2002-52-30, effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

subsection.subsectiontext: When an individual applies for registration under the Child Care Support Program administered by the minister, the individual must provide a criminal record check authorization to the minister.
The minister must not register an applicant who has not complied with subsection (1) and section 24.

change.changenote: Section 20 (1) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 2013-8-33, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: When an individual applies for registration under a prescribed program, the individual must provide a criminal record check authorization to the administrator.

change.changenote: Section 21 (1) BEFORE amended by 2002-52-31, effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

subsection.subsectiontext: A child care provider must provide a criminal record check authorization to the minister.

change.changenote: Section 21 (2) (b) BEFORE amended by 2002-52-31, effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

paragraph.paragraphtext: the minister must revoke the registration of a child care provider who has not provided the criminal record check authorization.

change.changenote: Section 21 (1) BEFORE amended by 2007-28-16, effective January 1, 2008 (BC Reg 386/2007).

subsection.subsectiontext: A child care provider must provide a criminal record check authorization to the administrator.

change.changenote: Section 21 (1) and (2) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 2013-8-34, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: A child care provider must provide a criminal record check authorization to the administrator

paragraph.paragraphtext: before the date prescribed by regulation, and
at least once every 5 years after the date on which the authorization is provided in compliance with paragraph (a).

subsection.subsectiontext: If a child care provider does not provide the criminal record check authorization as required by subsection (1) or section 23,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the child care provider must not work with children until the child care provider has provided the criminal record check authorization, and
the administrator must revoke the registration of a child care provider who has not provided the criminal record check authorization.

change.changenote: Section 21.1 was enacted by BC Reg 2013-8-35, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Section 22 (1) BEFORE amended by 2002-52-27, effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

subsection.subsectiontext: If an adjudicator determines that an outstanding charge or conviction indicates that the individual presents a risk of physical or sexual abuse to children and that determination is not overturned by an appeal panel under section 5,

change.changenote: Section 22 (1) (a) and (b) BEFORE amended by 2002-52-32, effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

paragraph.paragraphtext: if the individual is an applicant, the minister must not register the individual, or
if the individual is a child care provider, the minister must revoke the registration of the individual under the Child Care Support Program.

change.changenote: Section 22 (2) BEFORE amended by 2007-28-17, effective January 1, 2008 (BC Reg 386/2007).

subsection.subsectiontext: The minister must inform the police force, police department or designated policing unit, as defined in section 1 of the Police Act, that is responsible for policing the area in which the facility is located, if the minister believes that an individual who was determined to present a risk of physical or sexual abuse to children is continuing to operate a child care facility.

change.changenote: Section 22 (1) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 2013-8-36, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: If the deputy registrar determines that an outstanding charge or conviction indicates that the individual presents a risk of physical or sexual abuse to children and unless that determination is overturned by the registrar under section 5,

paragraph.paragraphtext: if the individual is an applicant, the administrator must not register the individual, or
if the individual is a child care provider, the administrator must revoke the registration of the individual under the prescribed program.

change.changenote: Section 22 (1.1) was added by BC Reg 2013-8-36, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Section 23 BEFORE amended by 2002-52-33, effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

subsection.subsectiontext: If a child care provider is charged with or convicted of a relevant offence subsequent to a criminal record check, the child care provider must promptly report the charge or conviction to the minister and provide to the minister a criminal record check authorization for a further criminal record check.

When the minister becomes aware that a child care provider has an outstanding charge for, or has been convicted of, a relevant offence, the minister must require the child care provider to provide a criminal record check authorization for a further criminal record check.

change.changenote: Section 23 (1) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 2013-8-21, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: If a child care provider is charged with or convicted of a relevant offence subsequent to a criminal record check, the child care provider must promptly report the charge or conviction to the administrator and provide to the administrator a criminal record check authorization for a further criminal record check.

change.changenote: Section 24 BEFORE amended by 2002-52-33, effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

section.sectiontext: A child care provider must not permit an individual who is over the age of 12, other than a parent of a child enrolled at the facility, to be ordinarily present on the premises where the unlicensed family child care facility is located, during the time that children enrolled in the facility are present, unless the child care provider has obtained a criminal record check authorization for that individual and provided it to the minister.

change.changenote: Section 24 BEFORE amended by BC Reg 2013-8-37, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

section.sectiontext: A child care provider must not permit an individual who is over the age of 12, other than a parent of a child enrolled at the facility, to be ordinarily present on the premises where the unlicensed family child care facility is located, during the time that children enrolled in the facility are present, unless the child care provider has obtained a criminal record check authorization for that individual and provided it to the administrator.

change.changenote: Part 5.1, sections 24.1 to 24.9 were enacted by BC Reg 2013-8-38, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Section 24.5 (1) (b) BEFORE amended by 2023-10-156(a), effective March 30, 2023 (Royal Assent).

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide to his or her registered specified organization a criminal record check authorization or a criminal record check verification authorization, as applicable,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: within 1 year of the date of notification, under section 24.1 (2), that the specified organization is a registered specified organization, and
at least once every 5 years after the date on which authorization is provided in compliance with subparagraph (i).

change.changenote: Section 24.5 (2) (b) BEFORE amended by 2023-10-156(b), effective March 30, 2023 (Royal Assent).

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide to his or her registered specified organization a criminal record check authorization or a criminal record check verification authorization, as applicable, at least once every 5 years after the date on which the volunteer provided to his or her registered specified organization the volunteer's last criminal record check authorization or criminal record check verification authorization.

change.changenote: Section 25 BEFORE repealed by 2002-52-34, effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

section.sectiontext: The minister must appoint one or more individuals to be adjudicators for the purpose of this Act.

change.changenote: Section 26 BEFORE repealed by 2002-52-34, effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).

section.marginalnote: Remuneration for adjudicator and appeal panel
section.sectiontext: An adjudicator or a member of an appeal panel may be paid

paragraph.paragraphtext: an allowance for reasonable travelling and incidental expenses necessarily incurred in carrying out a function under this Act, and
if the member is not a member of the Legislative Assembly or a public servant, remuneration at rates set by the Lieutenant Governor in Council.

change.changenote: Section 27 (d) was added by BC Reg 2013-8-39, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Section 27 (c) BEFORE amended by 2023-10-157, effective March 30, 2023 (Royal Assent).

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: include the individual's authorization to submit his or her fingerprints if necessary to verify the results of the criminal record check, and

change.changenote: Section 27.01 was enacted by BC Reg 2013-8-40, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).
Section 27.1 enacted by 2002-52-35, effective October 1, 2002 (BC Reg 238/2002).
Section 27.1 BEFORE amended by BC Reg 2013-8-41, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

section.sectiontext: The registrar may waive the payment of the prescribed fee payable for a criminal record check if the registrar considers the waiver to be in the public interest.

change.changenote: Section 27.2 enacted by 2002-52-35, effective July 15, 2002 (BC Reg 173/2002).
Section 27.2 (1) and (2) BEFORE amended by 2023-10-158, effective March 30, 2023 (Royal Assent).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar may delegate to a person any or all of his or her powers, duties or functions, including, without restriction, powers, duties or functions relating to a reconsideration under section 5.

The deputy registrar may delegate to a person any or all of his or her powers, duties or functions, including, without restriction, powers, duties or functions relating to a determination under section 4.

change.changenote: Section 28 (1) BEFORE amended by 2007-28-18(a), effective January 1, 2008 (BC Reg 386/2007).

subsection.subsectiontext: A person who contravenes section 6 (1), (2) or (3), 8 (1) or (2), 9 (2), 10 (2) (a) or (b), 11 (a) or (b), 12 (2) or (3), 13 (1), 14 (2), 15 (2) (a) or (b) or (3), 16 (1), (2) or (3), 17 (2), (3) or (4) or 21 (2) (a) is guilty of an offence and liable to a fine of up to $5 000.

change.changenote: Section 28 (2) BEFORE amended by 2007-28-18(b), effective January 1, 2008 (BC Reg 386/2007).

subsection.subsectiontext: A person who contravenes section 10 (1), 12 (1), 15 (1), 17 (1), 21 (1) or 23 (1) is guilty of an offence and liable to a fine of up to $50 for each day on which the contravention continues.

change.changenote: Section 28 (1) BEFORE amended by 2010-34-40, effective January 1, 2011 (BC Reg 352/2010).
Section 28 (1) and (2) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 2013-8-42, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: A person who contravenes section 10 (1), 12 (1), 15 (1), 17 (1), 17.2 (1), 17.4 (1), 17.7 (1), 17.9 (1), 21 (1) or 23 (1) is guilty of an offence and liable to a fine of up to $50 for each day on which the contravention continues.

change.changenote: Section 28.1 was enacted by 2007-28-19, effective January 1, 2008 (BC Reg 386/2007).
Section 28.1 (1) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 2013-8-43, effective November 30, 2013 (BC Reg 214/2013).

subsection.subsectiontext: The registrar may request a person who has a duty under section 8, 13, 17.1, 17.5 or 19 to ensure that criminal record checks are undergone to submit records or information if the registrar considers it necessary in determining whether the person's duty is being performed.
